en.value: The judge works in the court.
The lawyer works in a law firm.
The accused arrived at the trial in an expensive suit.
The victim was nervous about seeing her aggressor.
The judge advised that the trial could take 3 weeks to complete.
He was given 2 years in jail for his crime.
Many of the victim's family were present in the courtroom.
Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, have you reached a verdict?
We are all certain that he is guilty.
If she is innocent, she will walk free.
The man was ordered to pay a fine.
Giving your opinion on law and religion - Complex adjectives and adverbs
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Did you hear about the politician that was found [k]guilty[/k] of corruption last week?
Yes, I saw him on television. It was a very short [k]trial[/k], wasn't it?
Yes, they had found a lot of [k]evidence[/k] against him.
The crime usually carries a two year prison [k]sentence[/k], doesn't it?
Yes, usually between two and three years, but he was only given six months!
Is that all?! Did he have to pay any kind of [k]fine[/k]?
No, nothing at all. I think a lot of people were very surprised.
That's terrible. That's not [k]justice[/k]! I hate the way some people get special treatment.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Do you think that the legal system always gives justice correctly?
The word in bold is an adjective.
My child was behaving very badly, so we went home.
We use adjectives to give information about nouns:
A harsh sentence. = Gives us information about the noun 'sentence'
The word in bold is an adverb.
I fully agree with the writer's opinion.
We use adverbs to give us information about verbs or sometimes adjectives. They can give information about things such as 'time', 'place' and 'manner'.
I fully agree. = Gives information about the verb 'agree'. It tells us about how we agree.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Lots of adverbs are formed by adding ly to the adjective.

strong > strongly
quick > quickly
full > fully
Adjectives are usually placed before the noun they modify:

A complete disaster.
An amazing party.
Or after the verb 'to be', or related verbs ('feel', 'seem' etc.):

He was lucky.
She felt excited.
They looked tired.

Adverbs can be placed in different positions in a sentence. Some common positions are:
Between subject and verb (this is common with degree adverbs and intensifiers)
After the object of the verb:
There is a lot of [k]strong evidence[/k] that supports her position.
The facts [k]clearly show[/k] that he made a mistake.
Do you think that I am [k]completely wrong[/k]?
To be honest, I [k]don't fully agree[/k] with your point.
The newspaper article argues [k]the point clearly[/k].
The sentence looks backwards from a time in the future.
The votes will have been counted by 12 o'clock tomorrow.
This time next week we will vote for a new government.
The Prime Minister will have left the country by that time.
Future Simple tense looks forward to a future situation while Future Perfect tense is used to talk about an action that will be completed by a time in the future.

It will rain tomorrow.  (looking forward)
It will have rained by then.  (looking backwards from a time in the future)
The sentence uses the Future Perfect tense.
We won't have finished our work by then.
Will you be at the party on Saturday?
Daniel will have moved out of the house by the 17th.
We often use time phrases starting with by... with the Future Perfect tense:
I'll have finished by this time next week. They'll have left by the 15th. He'll have arrived by 8 o'clock.
[k]She[/k] [k]will[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]moved out[/k] [k]of the house[/k] [k]by the 20th of July.[/k]
To form the Future Perfect tense we use the auxiliary verbs will + have with the past participle of the main verb. We often use abbreviated forms:
I will have been = I'll have been
She will not have been = She won't have been
The company [k]will have hired[/k] 10 new employees by this time next year.
My boss [k]will be[/k] in Germany all week next week.
[k]Will you have[/k] finished the match by then?
My sister won't [k]have[/k] had her baby by then.
[k]I will have replaced|I'll have replaced[/k] my mobile phone by then.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
I think Debbie [k]won't have finished|will not have finished[/k] work by then.
[k]They will have arrived|They'll have arrived[/k] at the hotel by midnight.
[k]Will he have met[/k] your parents by then?
By 2050 the world's population [k]will have increased[/k] to 9 billion people.
